nodes.name: ZFC_Axiom_Extensionality
nodes.description: Two sets are equal if and only if they have the same elements
learning_objectives: Understand set equality, Apply extensionality principle
nodes.tooltip:
ZFC_Axiom_Extensionality
Two sets are equal if and only if they have the same elements
Type: Axiom
Complexity: Fundamental
Subject: Set Theory
Definition: ∀A ∀B (A = B ↔ ∀x (x ∈ A ↔ x ∈ B))
nodes.searchable: zfc_axiom_extensionality two sets are equal if and only if they have the same elements set_theory

nodes.name: Empty_Set
nodes.description: A set containing no elements, denoted ∅ or {}
examples: The set of natural numbers less than 0, The set of unicorns in reality
learning_objectives: Recognize the empty set, Use empty set in proofs
nodes.tooltip:
Empty_Set
A set containing no elements, denoted ∅ or {}
Type: Concept
Complexity: Basic
Subject: Set Theory
Prerequisites: ZFC_Axiom_Extensionality
Definition: ∅ = {x : x ≠ x} = {x : False}
nodes.searchable: empty_set a set containing no elements, denoted ∅ or {} set_theory

nodes.name: Finite_Set
nodes.description: A set with finitely many elements that can be counted
nodes.mathematical_definition: A set S is finite if ∃n ∈ ℕ such that |S| = n
examples: 3} has cardinality 3, The set of planets in our solar system
learning_objectives: Count elements in finite sets, Understand cardinality concept
nodes.tooltip:
Finite_Set
A set with finitely many elements that can be counted
Type: Concept
Complexity: Intermediate
Subject: Set Theory
Prerequisites: Empty_Set
Definition: A set S is finite if ∃n ∈ ℕ such that |S| = n
nodes.searchable: finite_set a set with finitely many elements that can be counted set_theory

nodes.name: Infinite_Set
nodes.description: A set that is not finite - contains infinitely many elements
nodes.mathematical_definition: A set S is infinite if ¬(∃n ∈ ℕ such that |S| = n)
examples: The set of natural numbers ℕ = {1
learning_objectives: Distinguish finite from infinite sets, Work with infinite cardinalities
nodes.tooltip:
Infinite_Set
A set that is not finite - contains infinitely many elements
Type: Concept
Complexity: Intermediate
Subject: Set Theory
Prerequisites: Finite_Set
Definition: A set S is infinite if ¬(∃n ∈ ℕ such that |S| = n)
nodes.searchable: infinite_set a set that is not finite - contains infinitely many elements set_theory

nodes.name: Countable_Set
nodes.description: A set that can be put in one-to-one correspondence with natural numbers
nodes.mathematical_definition: A set S is countable if ∃f: S → ℕ that is bijective, or S is finite
examples: The integers ℤ are countable via f(n) = n/2 if even
-(n+1)/2 if odd, The rational numbers ℚ are countable (Cantors diagonal)
learning_objectives: Prove sets are countable, Understand bijections with ℕ
nodes.tooltip:
Countable_Set
A set that can be put in one-to-one correspondence with natural numbers
Type: Concept
Complexity: Advanced
Subject: Set Theory
Prerequisites: Infinite_Set
Definition: A set S is countable if ∃f: S → ℕ that is bijective, or S is finite
nodes.searchable: countable_set a set that can be put in one-to-one correspondence with natural numbers set_theory

nodes.name: Power_Set
nodes.description: The set of all subsets of a given set
nodes.mathematical_definition: For set S, P(S) = {A : A ⊆ S}
learning_objectives: Construct power sets, Understand subset relationships
nodes.tooltip:
Power_Set
The set of all subsets of a given set
Type: Concept
Complexity: Intermediate
Subject: Set Theory
Prerequisites: Finite_Set
Definition: For set S, P(S) = {A : A ⊆ S}
nodes.searchable: power_set the set of all subsets of a given set set_theory

nodes.name: Cartesian_Product
nodes.description: The set of all ordered pairs from two sets
nodes.mathematical_definition: A × B = {(a,b) : a ∈ A ∧ b ∈ B}
learning_objectives: Form Cartesian products, Understand ordered pairs
nodes.tooltip:
Cartesian_Product
The set of all ordered pairs from two sets
Type: Concept
Complexity: Intermediate
Subject: Set Theory
Prerequisites: Finite_Set
Definition: A × B = {(a,b) : a ∈ A ∧ b ∈ B}
nodes.searchable: cartesian_product the set of all ordered pairs from two sets set_theory

nodes.name: Logical_Conjunction
nodes.description: Logical AND operation, true when both operands are true
nodes.mathematical_definition: P ∧ Q is true iff P is true and Q is true
examples: 2 > 1 AND 3 > 2 is true, 2 > 3 AND 3 > 2 is false
learning_objectives: Apply conjunction correctly, Build compound statements
nodes.tooltip:
Logical_Conjunction
Logical AND operation, true when both operands are true
Type: Concept
Complexity: Basic
Subject: Logic
Prerequisites: ZFC_Axiom_Extensionality
Definition: P ∧ Q is true iff P is true and Q is true
nodes.searchable: logical_conjunction logical and operation, true when both operands are true logic

nodes.name: Logical_Disjunction
nodes.description: Logical OR operation, true when at least one operand is true
nodes.mathematical_definition: P ∨ Q is true iff P is true or Q is true (or both)
examples: 2 > 1 OR 2 > 3 is true, 1 > 2 OR 3 > 4 is false
learning_objectives: Apply disjunction correctly, Distinguish inclusive vs exclusive OR
nodes.tooltip:
Logical_Disjunction
Logical OR operation, true when at least one operand is true
Type: Concept
Complexity: Basic
Subject: Logic
Prerequisites: Logical_Conjunction
Definition: P ∨ Q is true iff P is true or Q is true (or both)
nodes.searchable: logical_disjunction logical or operation, true when at least one operand is true logic

nodes.name: Universal_Quantification
nodes.description: Statement that a property holds for all elements in a domain
nodes.mathematical_definition: ∀x ∈ D, P(x) means P(x) is true for every x in domain D
examples: n ≥ 1 (all natural numbers are at least 1), ∀x ∈ ℝ
learning_objectives: Write universal statements, Prove universal properties
nodes.tooltip:
Universal_Quantification
Statement that a property holds for all elements in a domain
Type: Concept
Complexity: Advanced
Subject: Logic
Prerequisites: Finite_Set, Logical_Conjunction
Definition: ∀x ∈ D, P(x) means P(x) is true for every x in domain D
nodes.searchable: universal_quantification statement that a property holds for all elements in a domain logic

nodes.name: Existential_Quantification
nodes.description: Statement that a property holds for at least one element in a domain
nodes.mathematical_definition: ∃x ∈ D, P(x) means P(x) is true for some x in domain D
examples: n > 100 (there exists a natural number greater than 100), ∃x ∈ ℝ
learning_objectives: Write existential statements, Provide existence proofs
nodes.tooltip:
Existential_Quantification
Statement that a property holds for at least one element in a domain
Type: Concept
Complexity: Advanced
Subject: Logic
Prerequisites: Finite_Set, Logical_Disjunction
Definition: ∃x ∈ D, P(x) means P(x) is true for some x in domain D
nodes.searchable: existential_quantification statement that a property holds for at least one element in a domain logic
